title: EM Optimized Cryostat Sections (EMOCS) for Wide Scale Ultrastructural Imaging of Tissue Morphology Combined with Antigen Detection by Immunohistochemistry
content: Cryosections of lightly fixed and freeze-protected tissues are frequently used in the biomedical sciences due to their superior preservation of enzymatic activity (enzymatic histochemistry) and antigenicity (immunohistochemistry) combined with adequate preservation of histomorphology. “Cryostat” sections, which are prepared with a dedicated “cryostat” sectioning device, are most commonly used for tissue evaluation at the light microscope level and have the advantage of generating sections of many square millimeters, which is helpful for histologic context and finding regions of interest. Additionally, the thickness range of cryostat sections (2-10 micrometers) is compatible with efficient antibody penetration for immunohistochemistry applications. However, few laboratories have succeeded in routinely preparing cryostat sections with a quality high enough to be useful for immunogold electron microscopy, which requires both antigen preservation and acceptable ultrastructure and membrane contrast over wide imaging fields. The published efforts have mainly focused on a small range of cells or tissues and on sample preparation for TEM, which narrows the unobstructed field of view [1, 2].
